displayTitle: Are you ready to prioritise your data for publishing?
title: Are you ready to prioritise your data for publishing?

body:
Open data is supporting innovation and growth by revealing opportunities for businesses large and small to build new services, identify savings and improve operations.

In Paris, café owners are using open data to attract tourists to the city's most affordable coffees, while, in Iceland, farmers are using open data about the quality of their lambs to attract new customers.

UK startup CityMapper joined up available transport data to improve the ways in which citizens could travel. Since its inception in 2011, CityMapper has received $50m in funding and has expanded to cover 38 cities.

Open data stimulates innovation by removing barriers to access, use and shareability of data.
title: Innovation and growth in businesses

body:
The first thing to think about is what you are trying to achieve. What is your end goal for publishing your data openly?

Next, think about your potential users. What are their goals? How would your data help them to achieve their goals?

The most successful open data publications are where the goals of the data providers and the goals of the data users are aligned. It's rare that everyone starts out with identical goals, so look for areas where those goals overlap. The more closely aligned the goals are, the more successful the publication tends to be.

The physical activity sector is a great example of where the goal of an activity provider can align with the goal of the users. Activity providers want more people to be active through using their services, and users want to find appropriate activities that meet their individual needs.
title: Where do I start?

body:
Open data has the power to help grow economies, transform societies and increase efficiency.

Physical activity providers can use open data to get more people involved, create better experiences for participants and create new products and services that will help more people get active. 

Ready to get hands on? In the next module we explore how to prioritise which physical activity data to publish openly.

Previous module Next module
title: Ready to create impact?

body:
Physical activity providers can use open data to get more people involved, create better experiences for participants and run their organisations more efficiently. 

In this module, we will explore how the public sector, businesses and individuals in other sectors are already using open data to create impact and we will explore the potential impact that open data could have for the physical activity sector.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • Opportunities for the public sector 
  • Innovation and growth in business
  • Changing society
title: Creating impact from open data

body: There are three technical considerations as part of the standards for publishing open data, one of which is...
title: Technical considerations

_items.text: whether it can it be used on a computer
whether it takes up much bandwidth
what format the open data is published in

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data. The format in which the data is published in, the structure of the data and the channels through which the data is available.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data. The format in which the data is published in, the structure of the data and the channels through which the data is available.

displayTitle: Are you ready to ensure quality open data?
title: Are you ready to ensure quality open data?

_items.text: a little more important than it used to be
something that should be researched more
a crucial part of modern service delivery

_feedback.correct:

A new generation across the world has grown to expect a digitally literate and engaged public sector.

_incorrect.final:

body: Which of the following are errors in data that require cleaning?
title: Improving quality
instruction: Choose three answers and click Submit

_items.text: Multiple representations (e.g. "Nine thirty" and "09:30")
Lack of licence
Lack of granularity
Spelling errors
Redundant data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Spelling errors, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed to make sure your data is usable. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being unclean.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Spelling errors, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed to make sure your data is usable. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being unclean.

body:
Publishing open physical activity data can bring you a wide range of benefits, from more people using your facilities to better exposure for your activities online. But for both you and your users to enjoy those benefits, your data needs to be of a good enough quality to use. This module looks at what quality data is and how you can apply some simple checks to minimise problems.

Be aware that fixing problems with your data may take longer than you think. A careful cleaning process will save substantial time in the long-run and make your data much more useful to app developers and ultimately anyone who wants to take part in your activities!

Previous module
title: Quality open data

body: There are lots of valuable examples of open data initiatives bringing social, economic and environmental benefits. Are you ready to join the open data movement?
displayTitle: Are you ready to create impact from open data?
title: Are you ready to create impact from open data?

body:
There are many physical activity datasets that can be published as open data. Prioritising which data to publish openly first can be a difficult decision. Your organisation needs to prioritise data that will have the greatest impact both for your organisation and for your users, because data takes time to clean, publish and promote.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • Where do I start?
  • Why is opportunity data a good place to start?
  • What types of data are opportunity data?
title: Prioritising data to publish openly

body:
Publishing open physical activity data can bring you a wide range of benefits from more people using your facilities to better exposure for your activities online. But for both you and your users to enjoy those benefits, your data needs to be of a good enough quality to use.

  • What do we mean by 'open data quality'?
  • Where can I get help to make sure my data is good quality?
  • What are the badges that indicate quality for data?
  • How can I quickly and easily improve data quality?
displayTitle: How to make your data useful
title: How to make your data useful

body: Opportunity data should be a priority to publish openly, because...
displayTitle: Why is opportunity data a good place to start?
title: Why is opportunity data a good place to start?

_items.text: It is the data that is most relevant to consumers and the most likely to get them active
It is a highly economically valuable type of data
Providers will have access to all participantsâ€™ personal data

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Opportunity data is a good place to start when publishing open data, because it helps to meet the shared goal of getting more people active.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Opportunity data is a good place to start when publishing open data, because it helps to meet the shared goal of getting more people active.

body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. Governments, businesses and individuals can use open data to bring about social, economic and environmental benefits.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • What is open data?
  • What is data?
  • What makes data open?
  • Why does the physical activity sector need open data?
displayTitle: Open data in the physical activity sector
title: Open data in the physical activity sector

body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data becomes usable when made available in a common, machine-readable format.

Open data must be licensed. Its licence must permit people to use the data in any way they want, including transforming, combining and sharing it with others, even commercially.
title: What is open data?

body: Without data we can’t build information, and without information there is no new knowledge.
displayTitle: From raw material to new information and knowledge
title: From raw material to new information and knowledge
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Data
_items.body:
Data is the raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

Think of data as those locations, images, descriptions, reviews and prices that form the basis of information that can help you plan a holiday, for example.

_items.title: Information
_items.body:
Data becomes information when it is given a context.

Following on from the previous example, locations, images, descriptions and prices can all help provide information related to a tourist attraction.

The collection and presentation of data helps to form information.

_items.title: Knowledge
_items.body:
Knowledge is what is derived from information, and personalised for your needs.

Building knowledge is a process of turning information into choices.

Building on the previous example, knowing that no one in your family likes theme parks will help you to decide which places to avoid on holiday, and which would suit your family better.

body:
Data is open if anyone can access, use and share it.
There are some simple things to consider when defining openness:
title: What makes data open?
instruction: Click on the headings to see more.

_items.title: Limitations
_items.body:
For data to be open, it should have no limitations that prevent it from being used in any particular way.

Anyone should be free to use, modify, combine and share the data, even commercially.

_items.title: Cost
_items.body:
Open data must be free to use, but this does not mean that it must be free to access.

There is often a cost to creating, maintaining and publishing usable data.

Ideally, any fee for accessing open data should be no more than the reasonable reproduction cost of the unit of data that is requested.

This reproduction cost tends to be negligible for many datasets.

Live data and big data can incur ongoing costs related to reliable service provision.

_items.title: Reuse
_items.body:
Once the user has the data, they are free to use, reuse and redistribute it – even commercially.

Open data is measured by what it can be used for, not by how it is made available.

Aspects like format, structure and machine readability all make data more usable, and should all be carefully considered.

However, these do not make the data more open.

body: Open data is...
title: What is open data?

_items.text: information that we sell to businesses
data that anyone can access, use and share
data that is visible on the Web

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data must also be licensed to allow free usage and be available for commercial use.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data must also be licensed to allow free usage and be available for commercial use.

body: Data is...
title: What is data?

_items.text: numbers, words, maps and photos.
information posted on the Web.
the raw material of information and knowledge.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Data is the lowest level of raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Data is the lowest level of raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

body: Open data should be...
title: What makes data open?

_items.text: selectively released for a fee
free from restrictions for its use
restricted in its use

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

If something restricts the free use of the data, such as a non-commercial restriction, then this would not qualify as being open data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

If something restricts the free use of the data, such as a non-commercial restriction, then this would not qualify as being open data.

body: At any one time 25.6% of people in England are inactive. They face a diverse range of barriers, both emotional and practical, of which a lack of information on what is available is one. Publishing data openly has the power to help improve services, grow participation and create a healthier population. Open data can help get more people active.
displayTitle: Why does the physical activity sector need open data?
title: Why does the physical activity sector need open data?
instruction: Click on the headings to see more.

_items.title: Improving the users' experience
_items.body:
By publishing quality open data, providers will make it easier for websites and apps to reuse and share data, and create information that people can act on.

Enabling people to easily find and ultimately book activities will help increase participation.  

This will improve user satisfaction and ultimately create a better experience for participants.

The third module in this set looks at prioritising which data to publish openly.

_items.title: Creating innovation in the sector
_items.body:
Open data is driving a new wave of innovative apps, websites and products.  By publishing data openly, activity providers and national bodies can help stimulate the development of new ideas and ways for getting people active.

Knowing the services that competing providers offer can also help an activity provider refine their own offering and attract more customers.

_items.title: Benefiting activity providers
_items.body:
The more data about activities that is openly available, the more people are likely to attend those activities. Opening up data has the potential to increase both the number of participants and the variety of participants, as well as associated revenue for activity providers.

Open data can also improve efficiency for activity providers by avoiding repeat collection of data.

The next module explores further the impact of open data for the physical activity sector.

body: Open data is changing the way society works, by unlocking new social value and enabling data-driven decisions across a wide range of sectors. In the physical activity sector, this means getting more people active.
title: Changing society
instruction: Click the headings to explore further

_items.title: Changing behaviour
_items.body:
In the physical activity sector, open data can support behaviour change and get more people active

For someone who hasn't done any physical activity since school, data can answer the practical questions and help put them at ease - what equipment is provided and what do they need to bring? What should they wear? What level of fitness is expected?

For someone who travels regularly for work, being presented with suggested options for activities based on their calendar location information, dates, and their preferred activity types would enable them to continue to be active, despite a busy schedule.

Whatever stage someone is at with their physical activity, open data can help. Module 3 explores in more detail how publishing data openly can help get more people active.

_items.title: Improving health and wellbeing
_items.body:
Knowing what physical activities opportunities are available can help doctors recommend activities to their patients that are beneficial for their health.

For individuals, Grace is a messaging platform designed to help users with their mental wellbeing. Grace enables users to record their thoughts and feelings anonymously and to see their responses over a period of time, particularly any trends of mood changes.

Grace also offers guidance from government and charity websites, including physical activity opportunities in their local area.

_items.title: Meeting digital expectations
_items.body:
Many opportunities to do physical activity are hidden away in old old-fashioned websites, social media groups, PDFs or printed flyers.

Publishing this data openly in a standardised format enables consumers to easily discover what activities are available to them.

To find the nearest available tennis court, users are likely to search using a mapping application, like Google maps. However this is not the only way users expect to be able to find activities. Open data can enable many different services to provide directory listings to your services. 

Open data released by Transport for London is now used in over 800 mobile applications (including Google Maps). These apps meet the digital expectations of all types of users, from the occasional traveller, to daily commuters and those who require assistance with their journeys.

Find out more about data standards for the physical activities sector.

body: Open data is driving innovation and growth by...
title: Innovation and growth in business

_items.text: being made available on the Web
motivating innovators to use public sector data
revealing opportunities to build new services and improve operations

_feedback.correct:

_incorrect.final:

_incorrect.final:

body: The Open Data Institute advocates the use of its own quality marque known as...

_items.text: Open Data Certificates
the ODI big green tick
the ODI stamp of approval

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The Open Data Institute has developed Open Data Certificates which include practical and social requirements alongside in-depth legal and technical guidelines to consider when publishing open data.

body: There are four helpful things to remember when thinking about opening your data. Can you remember them?
displayTitle: Are you ready for open physical activity data?
title: Are you ready for open physical activity data?

body: Badges are often added to open data to demonstrate their quality. These badges are designed to give users of the data such as app developers some certainty about their usefulness.  There are two key badges of quality for open data:
displayTitle: What are the badges that indicate quality for data?
title: What are the badges that indicate quality for data?

_items.title: 5 Stars
_items.body:
The '5 Stars of linked open data' indicate that a dataset meets the basic legal definition of open and has some technical characteristics that make it useful for others.

The 5 Stars were developed by inventor of the Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee, in 2001. The 5 Stars make recommendations for the format and structure of the data.

_items.title: ODI Open Data Certificates
_items.body:
The Open Data Institute's Open Data Certificates badge indicates that a dataset meets basic practical, social, legal and technical guidelines.

The certificates badge is a self-assessment questionnaire for publishers to assess and benchmark the full usability of a dataset.  Take me to the ODI Open Data Certificates site.

body: Open data becomes usable when...
title: What makes open data useable?

_items.text: it is imported into a common system
the government publishes it
a person can understand it, software like apps and maps can useÂ it and it is made available under an open licence

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data becomes usable when a person can understand it, software like apps and maps can use it and it is made available under an open licence.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it, machines can manipulate it and it is made available under an open licence.

body: The public sector benefits from open data initiatives in many ways:
title: Opportunities for the public sector
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Supporting growing economies
_items.body:
To support the emergence of new data-driven businesses and the growth of existing ones, the public sector needs to publish key datasets.

The public sector also needs to support data infrastructure that connects data with those who use it.

In return, the public sector is reaping the benefits of a growing data economy, such as in Finland where SMEs with access to open data grew 15% faster than those without.

Take me to the Finnish case study

_items.title: Improved service delivery
_items.body:
The availability of detailed open data is essential to improving delivery of services for businesses and individuals.

The Environment Agency released 1,500 datasets as part of #opendefra. Publishing LIDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) data openly has enabled optimisation of rooftop solar cell installation. Publishing flood data openly made it possible for The Red Cross to build an app combining the flood data and Met Office weather warnings to issue real-time alerts about severe weather.

In the transport sector, Transport for London, released their travel data and enabled developers to provide consumer-friendly services, providing customers with an estimated £58 million per year in saved time.

_items.title: Efficiency savings
_items.body:
In the public sector, the Government of South Australia saves $3.2m annually on Freedom of Information requests through proactively releasing data.

Startup Prescribing Analytics – a joint venture between NHS doctors and technologists – used open data to identify a £200m annual saving for the NHS if they were to switch to own-brand statins and utilise more efficient delivery routes.

body: A good place to start when prioritising which data to publish openly is by...
title: Where do I start?

_items.text: Writing a data strategy
Publishing all of your data
Identifying the shared goals of the data provider and the data user

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

The most successful open data publications are where the goals of the data owners and the data users are aligned.  The more closely aligned the goals are, the more successful the publication tends to be.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The most successful open data publications are where the goals of the data owners and the data users are aligned.  The more closely aligned the goals are, the more successful the publication tends to be.

body: Examples of opportunity data are...
displayTitle: What types of data are opportunity data?
title: What types of data are opportunity data?
instruction: Choose all that apply, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Location, activity type & cost
Difficulty, fitness level & fun-factor
Popularity, ease & distance from transport
Leisure centre staff wages

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Location, activity, cost, difficulty, fitness level, fun-factor, popularity, ease and distance are all examples of opportunity data.

Staff wages are not a type of opportunity data. Moreover, wage data is personal data and therefore should not made open without explicit permission of those involved and, in most cases, suitable anonymisation.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Location, activity, cost, difficulty, fitness level, fun-factor, popularity, ease and distance are all examples of opportunity data.

Staff wages are not a type of opportunity data. Moreover, wage data is personal data and therefore should not made open without explicit permission of those involved and, in most cases, suitable anonymisation.

body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data is a raw material for the digital age but, unlike coal, timber or diamonds, it can be used by anyone and everyone at the same time.

Any restrictions imposed on the use of open data will limit its potential for creating new value.

Open data can bring diverse benefits to the physical activity sector. It has the power to help improve services, grow participation and create a healthier population. Open data can help get more people active.

Ready to make a difference? In the next module, we will explore ways that open data could create impact for the physical activity sector.

Next module
displayTitle: Open data in the physical activity sector
title: Open data in the physical activity sector

body:
Any physical activity dataset can be made open provided it does not contain personal data or sensitive information.

Your organisation needs to prioritise data that will make the greatest impact both for your organisation and for potential users, because data takes time to clean, publish and promote.

In the next module, we look at why you should make your data useful and usable before you publish it and how to do that. 

Previous module Next module
displayTitle: Choosing the right data to publish
title: Choosing the right data to publish

_items.title: What it is
_items.body: What type of activity is this? For example, yoga, hockey or fencing.

_items.title: Where it is
_items.body:
The location where the activity takes place or the address of the activity provider.

There may be more than one location, such as a start and an end location for an event or walking route.

_items.title: When it is
_items.body:
The time and date when the activity would take place. This could be over a broad range (e.g. this weekend), or a specific time (e.g. 6pm on Wednesday).

There may be multiple times; for example cycle rides may have a gathering time and a ride time, or the event might be one off or recurring.

_items.title: Who it's for
_items.body: Is the activity suitable for beginners or targeted at people with more experience? Are there restrictions, such as age group, accessibility, or gender?

_items.title: How much
_items.body:
Is the activity free, does it require membership or can I make a one-off payment? 

Are there additional costs such as lockers or equipment hire?

_items.title: Requirements
_items.body: Do I need to wear something specific or bring any safety equipment? Do I need to have a qualification to do this activity?

_items.title: How to get in contact
_items.body:
How do users get in contact with the provider? This might include an email address, phone number or a website address. 

Be careful to check that the organiser has given permission for these details to be shared, as details such as individual names, phone numbers and email addresses are personal data.

displayTitle: What types of data are opportunity data?
title: What types of data are opportunity data?

body:
Opportunity data informs consumers about what, where and when activities are happening. Such data can also include the cost of accessing that activity.

Examples could include details of badminton court availability, details and costs of yoga classes through to the timetable of a swimming pool. Opportunity data does not include personal data unless permitted by the provider, for example the contact details to book a yoga class or community football pitch.

The headings below explore the different types of data that make up opportunity data.
displayTitle: What types of data are opportunity data?
title: What types of data are opportunity data?
instruction: Click on the headings to explore further

body: What does open data have the power to do?
displayTitle: Why does the physical activity sector need open data?
title: Why does the physical activity sector need open data?

_items.text: Give access to other datasets
Improve services, grow participation and create a healthier population.
Make the sports providers accountable

_feedback.correct:
That's right.

Open data about physical activities can improve services, grow participation and create a healthier population.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open data about physical activities can improve services, grow participation and create a healthier population.

body:
Across the physical activity sector, a key blocker to increasing participation is helping people understand what, when and where physical activity sessions happen. This type of data is known as opportunity data.  

Publishing opportunity data as open data will help achieve the shared goal of getting more people active. It is relatively low effort for relatively high rewards.
displayTitle: Why is opportunity data a good place to start?
title: Why is opportunity data a good place to start?
instruction: Click on the headings to explore further

_items.title: Low effort
_items.body:
Publishing opportunity data as open data is relatively low effort. It is data that activity providers tend to collect as part of their normal business activities (see below for examples of opportunity data).

Opportunity data does not include personal data, unless permitted by the provider. Personal data is data relating to an identified or identifiable individual. It is protected by the Data Protection Act and should not be normally be published by an organisation without suitable anonymisation.  

Opportunity data may include personal data if permitted by the provider, for example the contact details to book a yoga class or community football pitch.

_items.title: High reward
_items.body:
Open opportunity data can be turned into useful information and enable participants to easily find activities that match their needs.

It can drive competition between providers, improve their services as well as increase reach and revenue. 

Professionals, such as doctors can use opportunity data to make informed recommendations to their patients. 

Open opportunity data can also enable innovation in the sector as new businesses and providers identify gaps in the market.

Module 2 explores the impact of open data in other sectors in more detail.

However, in order for open opportunity data to be beneficial it needs to be accurate, consistent and up to date. Module 4 explores how you can make your data useful.

body:
Open data is only useful when it is easy to understand and simple to use. If your data is messy, people will have trouble using it. This problem is even worse when the 'person' using it isn't a person at all but a software programme. If you give messy data to an app or a map, it won't display properly which means no one can use it effectively.

When we talk about open data quality, we mean that the data can be understood by a person and used by software like apps and maps. The more people that have access to your data - either directly, or via an app or a map - the more people will interact with the services you provide as their consumer needs are being met.
displayTitle: What do we mean by 'open data quality'?
title: What do we mean by 'open data quality'?

body:
Errors and inconsistencies often occur in data. They are the main barrier to producing good quality data. Common errors include duplicate entries, missing data, inconsistent use of abbreviations, spelling mistakes and different formats. 

Thankfully there is a free tool out there to help you check for and fix these errors much faster than you can in a spreadsheet. To deal with messy data, we recommend OpenRefine, which can help you quickly clean large datasets. Unlike Excel and other spreadsheet programmes, OpenRefine allows you to record the changes you make and can automatically apply cleaning functions to other datasets.

If you're publishing your own open data, OpenRefine can help you ensure quality open data before you publish.

If you're using somebody else's open data, why not get in contact with them to let you know you've improved their dataset? Alternatively, you could republish it yourself, as long as you remember to attribute your source!

To get started with OpenRefine, follow our exercise here.
displayTitle: How can I quickly and easily improve dataÂ quality?
title: How can I quickly and easily improve dataÂ quality?

body:
You've come to the end of this eLearning, but it's not the end of your journey with open data.

Got some data you want to publish?  Get in touch: hello@openactive.io

Interested in shaping the open data standards for the physical activity sector? Join the W3C community group

Want to learn more? Take a look at what's out there for you to learn.
title: Continuing your open data journey

body:
Quality of data is important, however understanding what quality data is to your audience is also important as outlined in this article.

To help you understand the quality of your data, there are some basic requirements that you should consider. Not all of these requirements are straightforward and some might require you to check with your technical team or your booking system provider. However, answering them will give you a clear picture of whether your data meets quality standards. Browse the categories below to learn about the key questions you need to ask.
displayTitle: Where can I get help to make sure my data is good quality?
title: Where can I get help to make sure my data is good quality?
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Legal requirements
_items.body:
Legal requirements

Open data must be released under an open licence. Find out more about licensing in this module.

In addition to the open licence, there are three legal requirements that need to be considered. You must:

  • Protect sensitive information like personal data.
  • Preserve the rights of data owners.
  • Promote correct use of the data.

_items.title: Practical requirements
_items.body:
It is important that open data can be found and relied upon by users.

This means that open data publishers must:

  • Link to the data from their website, rather than just publishing information in PDFs.
  • Update the data regularly if it changes.
  • Commit to continue to make the data openly available.

_items.title: Technical requirements
_items.body:
There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data:

  • The channels through which the data is available.
  • The format in which the data is published.
  • The structure of the data.

Putting any sort of data on a website is a good start, as this is the best channel.

Putting that data out there as text in a PDF is not a very useable format (you can find out more about data formats in this eLearning module). 

Structuring the data inside a spreadsheet (Excel or equivalent) and linking this spreadsheet from the website is better.

_items.title: Social requirements
_items.body:
For data use to be sustainable, it is important to have an engaged community of users. The best datasets have:

  • Active support channels.
  • Discussion groups and forums.
  • Published how-to guides on working with the data.
